translated: Sutra of the Wise and the Foolish, Scroll 4
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 2: Desire, Section on Desire
Desire, I know your origin, born from the mind's thoughts;
If I do not think of you, then you do not exist.
Formerly the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Garden in the country of Sravasti.
At that time, the World-Honored One, together with his attendant Ananda, put on his robe, took his bowl, entered the city of Sravasti, finished his alms round, and left the city.
There was a woman carrying a child and holding a jar to draw water from a well. A man with an upright appearance was sitting to the right of the well, playing a lute to amuse himself.

At that time, the woman, with excessive lustful intentions, was infatuated with that person. The man also had rampant lustful intentions and was infatuated with the woman. The woman, confused by lustful intentions, tied a rope around the child's neck and hung it in the well. She then pulled it back out, and the child died. She was sorrowful and distressed, crying out to the heavens and shedding tears, and spoke a verse, saying:
I wish to know your origin, you are born from the mind with thoughts;
If I do not think of you, then you do not exist.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to Ä€nanda:
The verses you heard earlier were spoken by the Buddhas of the past, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River. You should recite and practice them well.
In the afternoon, gather the assembly and proclaim these verses among the people.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had finished his meal, he put away his three robes, gathered the great assembly, and went to the Hall of Universal Assembly, where he sat among the people.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the bhiká¹£us:

This morning, I took Ä€nanda into the city to beg for food. After completely going around, I left the city and saw a woman holding a child and a jar, going to the well to draw water. Not far from the well, there was a man playing a lute for his own enjoyment.

The two people saw each other and each aroused lustful thoughts. They stared at each other without blinking. They mistakenly tied the child's neck and hung him in the well. They then pulled him out again, but the child had already died.
They grieved and wailed, and then spoke a verse, saying:
I know your origin, desire, which arises from thought.
If I do not think of you, then you do not exist.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

The raging fire of lust can burn away the roots of all goodness. Those who are wanton with lust do not recognize good and evil, nor do they distinguish between pure and impure conduct, nor do they know the path of liberation from bondage.
Such people eventually become shameless. They would rather lose their relatives and suffer humiliation than neglect their lustful nature and go against their desires.
Because of lust, they may kill their parents, siblings, or sisters, and thus receive their retribution.

Or due to the sin of indulgence in sex and the five heinous crimes, one is executed by the king and suffers an evil retribution, like a wild fire burning the trees on the side. Having deeply sinned oneself, one also involves one's relatives.
People, due to sexual desire, disobey the Buddha, disrespect the Dharma, and slander the noble assembly, and are ridiculed by the sages and worthies.
I will now explain the root of sexual misconduct. You should listen well!

In the past, there was a man who was unrestrained in sexual misconduct. He was the only son born to his parents. One night, when it was dark and thundering, he took his sword and arrows to the village of a prostitute.
At that time, his mother noticed and immediately grabbed him, trying to persuade him:
Tonight is dark, gloomy, and thundering. If you don't succeed, you will be harmed by others. I have few merits and only have this one son. Meeting with evil ones, I have no one to rely on.
The son replied to his mother:
I must go and cannot stay any longer.
The mother knew his mind was set and bowed to her son.
'Stay here for the night and go tomorrow.'
The son said to his mother:
'Quickly let me go, or if you go against my wishes I will kill you.'
The mother said to her son:
'Rather have me killed, I cannot bear to see you harmed by others.'
The son again said to his mother:
'Quickly let me go, if you do not agree I will kill you right now.'
The mother said to her son:
'I would rather die than let you go.'
The son then drew his sword, killed his mother, and without considering the grave consequences in the afterlife, went to the man's house, knocked on the door, and called out softly. The woman said:
'Who are you?'
The man replied in verse:
The faculties of lust and anger are weak, deluded by thoughts,
Not considering various tasks, covered by ignorance.
Remembering you killed your mother, subdued like your slave,
Standing outside the gate, like a guest serving as a messenger.
At that time, the woman again saw him from afar and asked:
Have you really killed your mother?
He replied:
I have indeed killed her.
The woman asked:
Why did you kill your mother?
The man replied:
My mother would not let me come here.
The woman said:
You do not need to enter the house.
At that time, the woman replied in verse:
Alas, you are ungrateful, having harmed your mother, committing a sinful offense,
How can I bear to see your face?
You should quickly leave my house.
Parents hold and raise you, enduring various hardships for their child,
Walking on the ground after killing your mother, the ground does not collapse under you.
Standing with no compassion or kindness, harming your relatives,
I am an outsider, how can I bring you kindness and virtue?
At that time, the man replied:
Because you have killed your mother and committed boundless crimes, I have shown you a little leniency and opened the door for you. For a moment, we were able to talk and then you returned home.
The woman said:
Listen to my verse:
It is better to enter a burning charcoal pit, jump from a mountain into a deep valley,
or hold a seven-step snake than to associate with a fool.
At that time, the two of them each went their separate ways.
The man returned home and on the way encountered a vicious bandit who killed him. He died and entered the AvÄ«ci Hell, where he received punishment for countless kalpas.

The calamity of lust is immeasurable. It starts small but gradually grows to burn the body. One falls into the path oneself and also involves others. One does not reach the ultimate, yet still drinks poison and makes others drink it as well.
Therefore, it is said: Lust should not be indulged in.
Love and desire give rise to worry, love and desire give rise to fear, without love and desire,
what worry and what fear?

Love and desire give rise to worry, perhaps losing a wife, being taken away by others, or having a long illness, or the husband traveling far for a long time without returning, therefore it is said, love and desire give rise to worry.
Love and desire give rise to fear, being taken away by the powerful and wealthy, or having a long illness with life hanging by a thread, or going to another place.
Therefore it is said, love and desire give rise to fear.
Without love and desire, what is meant by without love and desire?
The two types of people, the non-returners and the arhats, are without worry and without fear.
Why is it so?
Because they have already left behind all worries and have nothing to fear or be difficult about.

Those who have worries and fears are those in the desire realm and form realm. Those who have ended worries and fears in the desire realm are those who have attained the stage of non-returner. Those who have ended afflictions in the three realms and do not give rise to thoughts of worries and fears are arhats. Therefore it is said, Without any desires, what worries and fears are there?
Delight gives rise to worries, delight gives rise to fears. Without any delight,
what worries and fears are there?

As for delight giving rise to worries, those who make music and enjoy the five desires may be disliked by the king, who wants to confiscate their musical instruments, causing them to give rise to worries.
Or they may be sent far away to other places by the king, giving rise to worries in the process.
Or they may suffer from a chronic illness, bedridden and losing their eyesight, fearing for their life and giving rise to fear, all due to those musical instruments leading to the loss of their life.

Or there may be a king whose lineage has lost the country and position, with matters no longer under their control. Recalling the places of amusement when they were still powerful and noble, they give rise to sorrow and eventually become seriously ill.

Or if there are old grudges wanting to harm one's life, watching and capturing day and night, and giving rise to thoughts of worry and distress in the midst of this, therefore it is said: 'Dwelling in what is delightful gives rise to worry, dwelling in what is delightful gives rise to fear.'
What is meant by 'not dwelling in what is delightful'?
Arhats abandon the five kinds of delight and amuse themselves with the delight of the Dharma.
Just as Nanda once addressed the Buddha, saying:
Not seeing my SundarÄ«, my mind will never be at ease.
The World-Honored One told Nanda:ğŸ”½What is there to be satisfied with in dissatisfaction?
What is there to enjoy in dissatisfaction?ğŸ”½What is there to love in dissatisfaction?
What is there to enjoy in the absence of love?
You now let your mind run wild, without being satisfied, your aspirations always burning,
when will they ever cease?
Therefore, you should now contemplate the thought of impurity within, and you will suddenly awaken and gain understanding in your mind.
The reason you have not yet gained understanding is because you have not contemplated this thought.
Because of not contemplating, lust, anger, and delusion become rampant. Therefore, Nanda, endure, be diligent, and with one mind contemplate the impurity of the body.
Why is it so?

It is difficult to obtain a human body, and it is also difficult to encounter the sages. It is also difficult to have all the faculties complete, and it is also difficult to encounter the appearance of the Buddhas.
Like the udumbara flower, which appears only from time to time, it is also difficult to encounter the opportunity to hear the true Dharma.
Resting in the unconditioned, always happily at ease, all comes from the true Dharma to reach the other shore.
Therefore, Nanda, be mindful of being cautious and contemplate the true Dharma, giving rise to the thought of impurity, and you will be able to reach the realm of the unconditioned.
Therefore, it is said: Dwelling in pleasure gives rise to worry, dwelling in pleasure gives rise to fear. Without dwelling in pleasure, what worry is there, what fear?
The Buddha further spoke a verse, saying:
The fruit is sweet at first but bitter later, lust and anger are also like this.
Later one receives the retribution of suffering, experiencing it for countless eons.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The foolish ones are burned and cooked, always in a raging fire,
Seized by the jailers, like an elephant controlled by a hook.
In the past, the Buddha and his disciples spoke of the suffering aggregates.
The sutra says:
People attached to desires praise each other, saying:
'The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama and the brÄhmaá¹‡as always talk about preventing the future, fearing that future desires will defile and pollute.
Unlike us, whose minds are dyed with wonderful colors, enjoying the five desires and the pleasure of fine touch, what is there to lose?

' If there are sentient beings who stubbornly rely on this Dharma and create unwholesome actions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they will enter the hells. Having already been born in the hells, they will only then realize and repent to each other:
'We did not believe the words of the Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, saying that desires are defiled and impure conduct.
Because of this sexual impurity, we experience immeasurable suffering and have no hope of escape. Who can we blame for this, since we created it ourselves?'
Therefore it is said, the fruit is sweet first and bitter later, just as there are fruits that are sweet in the mouth and delightful at the time, but later they will definitely cause illness.

It is said that parables delight and enlighten the wise. Some wise people achieve through encouragement, some wise people are reprimanded and restrained, some wise people observe their intentions and are able to receive teachings, some wise people are gradually led and advanced and are able to cross over, and some wise people travel far and observe worldly affairs and awaken on their own.
The World-Honored One observes and follows the intentions of those who are attached, and uses what to treat them. Sentient beings gradually have their intentions enlightened.

Receiving the TathÄgata's teachings, they are ashamed and feel guilty, gradually exhausting their bonds, and their defiled minds attain liberation. Only then do they know that sexual desire is a disease that is sweet first and bitter later.
Hard wood, iron, copper, and tin, these are not as strong as
The good dye that is attached to that color, this strength is the strongest.

In the past, there was a person who encountered an incident and was imprisoned in an iron prison. He secretly devised a way to escape his crime, either relying on powerful people, using wealth, or relying on his family background, to avoid his offense.

The fetters of desire and love cannot be unraveled by ordinary people. Only the Buddhas who appear in the world, with the blazing flames of wisdom, burn down the entangled thickets of the mountains and fields, and with the sharp sword of wisdom, cut off the seven original bonds, and then one can attain liberation.

In the past, there was a person who encountered an incident and was imprisoned. He happened to meet a group of monks lecturing on the Dharma. The criminal asked the jailer to temporarily go to the lecture to listen to the Dharma. He happened to hear a bhiká¹£u reciting the sÅ«tra in the quiet of midnight:
Bound by old age, bound by birth, bound by sickness, bound by death, bound in this world and the next.
At that time, the criminal's relatives and clansmen sought the king's pardon, and he was then released from his crime.
At that time, all the criminal's relatives, acquaintances, and friends went to the criminal's house to celebrate together:
We hear that you have been released, and we are very happy for you.
The man replied:
Why do you think I'm being deceived?
The bonds I was in were much worse than those of a king, as I heard the bhiká¹£us chanting the sÅ«tras last night.
The people asked:
Even though you have been released, you are still confused?
The man replied:
I am not confused, but you all are mistaken. The bonds I was in were not untied by the king.
If all of you relatives who love me see me, please allow me to go forth and enter the path.
The relatives advised him, telling him of the difficulties:
With parents, relatives, sons, and daughters accomplished, why would you abandon them and greedily pursue the path?
The man replied:
I have previously vowed to go forth and study.
The relatives earnestly requested him to stay for a while.
After seven more days, they recovered from their fatigue and regained their strength. As they left the house, they encountered a monk reciting scriptures in a quiet manner, who spoke this verse:
Hardwood, iron, copper, and tin, these are not as strong as
the strong attachment to beautiful colors.
They returned to the house and told their five relatives:
My mind is not inclined to stay at home, I wish to be allowed to go forth and cultivate the unsurpassed holy life.
At that time, the five relatives immediately allowed them to go forth.
They diligently practiced day and night without rest, attained the fruit of arhatship, forever left behind bondage and attachment, and no longer transmigrated in the cycle of birth and death.
Among bonds, the firm ones are difficult to untie,
but one can sever them by focusing on the essentials, without observing the cutting off of desire and attachment.

As for the firmest among bonds, affection and attachment are all bonds. Only the Buddhas, upon arising, hold the vajra mind, which is firm and difficult to destroy. With the adornment of various virtues, they abandon evil and do not give rise to conditions for wrongdoing, and are able to sever all evil. Therefore, it is called the firmest among bonds.

As for the slow and difficult to untie among streams, streams flow within realms, being born in the middle, heading towards the middle. Now I will explain a parable for you, and the wise will understand through the parable.

In the past there was a king whose grace and kindness were all-encompassing, and he granted a great amnesty to the world. All those in prison with heavy chains were released.ğŸ”½Among them, some beings were disgusted with bondage and could not bear prison, always aspiring to be far away and quickly escape from prison, with no wish to stay.

There were also beings who enjoyed being in prison, their minds longing for it, and enjoyed hearing the sounds of suffering and distress, so they stayed in prison and were unwilling to leave. Therefore, it is said, The slow and difficult to untie among streams.
The reason for the slow ones is that they encounter amnesty and grace but are unwilling to leave.
What has been accumulated in the past, the good deeds and various merits, can then cut it off. Therefore, it is said that this is the essential point for cutting it off.
Not looking back at brothers, family business, and relatives, not observing the cutting off of desire and love, desire and love have already been cut off, forever without any remainder.
The eight matters for crossing the world are sworn by two oaths.
What are the two?
First, the oath of wisdom, second, the oath of exhaustion.
With these two oaths, one swears to deliver sentient beings.
The myriad wonderful colors in the world, this is not called desire,
The desires of the world remain in the world for a long time, only the wise can be aware of it.
In the past when the Buddha was in the world, the bhiká¹£us said to each other:
We should abandon the food of the saá¹ƒgha and beg for alms in the human realm.

The reason is that when the begging monks travel among the people, they get to see extremely wonderful sights, hear extremely wonderful sounds, smell extremely wonderful fragrances, and touch extremely wonderful smoothness.

At that time, the World-Honored One, with his heavenly ear that is pure, quiet, and free from defilements, heard the monks talking to each other, each giving rise to longing and attachment to worldly glory.
Then the World-Honored One sent a message to gather them in the lecture hall. The monks then gathered in the lecture hall.
The Buddha told the monks:
What do you think, monks?

I have already told you that when the begging monks travel among the people, they get to see extremely wonderful sights, hear extremely wonderful sounds, smell extremely wonderful fragrances, and touch extremely wonderful smoothness.
What do you think, monks?
Is the mind light and floating?

You should contemplate form, sound, smell, taste, and touch as if they were a blazing fire, and then add oil and ghee to it, causing it to burn even more fiercely. You should double your efforts in contemplating form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
Those bhiká¹£us who are able to restrain themselves, begging for alms outside while always harboring fear,
thinking: 'Is it easy to accept the offerings of faith from others?
Causing the donors to run in all directions, exhausting their thoughts and efforts to obtain wealth, and then reducing their possessions to give in charity;
I now have few virtues and fear that I will not be able to digest it.'

Contemplating those donors when they are about to give, their minds wish to give with faith as if they do not wish to receive, contemplating their own bodies as if they have a serious illness, the given objects as if they were medicine, thinking of secluded places as if they had encountered death, always focusing their minds on cultivating various wholesome roots, contemplating women as if they were a cemetery - in this way, they beg for alms in the human realm.
Those who are attached to form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas, and rely on the path, are called great thieves.
At that time, Venerable ÅšÄriputra asked MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila:
What do you think, Kauá¹£á¹­hila!

Are the eyes the characteristics of form, and is form the characteristic of the eyes? Are the ears, nose, tongue, body, and subtle dharmas the characteristics of the mind, and is the mind the characteristic of dharmas?
At that time, MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila replied to ÅšÄriputra:

The eyes are not the characteristics of form, and form is not the characteristic of the eyes. The ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind are not the characteristics of dharmas, and dharmas are not the characteristics of the mind.
The so-called characteristics are the attachment to one's own desires, which are called the characteristics of bondage.
He further gave an analogy to explain himself:
It is like a white ox and a black ox being tied up in the same place, or being tied up together with the same yoke.
What do you think, ÅšÄriputra?
Can someone say that a white ox is tied to a black ox, and a black ox is tied to a white ox, as an equal bondage?
He replied:ğŸ”½No.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
It is not that a white ox is tied to a black ox, nor that a black ox is tied to a white ox. The so-called bondage refers to ropes, halters, or yokes. This is called bondage.
Thus, ÅšÄriputra!

The eye is not the characteristic of form, form is not the characteristic of the eye. The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are not the characteristics of dharmas, dharmas are not the characteristics of the mind. The arising of greed and self-enjoyment in this is called characteristics.
Therefore it is said, The world accommodates various wonderful forms, but this is not called desire.
Human desires are impermanent, internal desires are permanent bondage,
This cessation does not accept existence, other destinies do not accept rebirth.

As for human desires are impermanent, desires are impermanent and subject to decay, changing and unstable, not to be relied upon. Human desires do not remain for long, they may be lost or stolen by others, therefore they are impermanent and cannot last.

Deeply attached to inner desires, they become tainted with the spirit. The mind is the head of calamity, and the body and mouth are affected by it. Therefore it is said, Inner desires are always binding.

Sometimes they are harmed by powerful and watchful enemies. Such desires are difficult to control and difficult to restrain. They cannot be retained by one's own power, nor can one avoid going to other existences. Nor do they wish to be born in this world or the next. Therefore it is said, If one wishes for desires to last in the world, only the wise can truly understand.
Desiring to give rise to uncontaminated practices, with a mind always filled with wishes,
Not being bound by desires in the mind, one ultimately reaches the highest stage.
As for desiring to give rise to uncontaminated practices, desires can be both wholesome and unwholesome. Wholesome desires may be either contaminated or uncontaminated.
Uncontaminated desires extinguish all craving. Contaminated desires are not discussed here.
With a mind always filled with wishes means that all wholesome dharmas completely fill the body.
As for not being bound by desires in the mind, the mind is not defiled or stained by that mind, and therefore it is said, not being bound by desires in the mind.
As for the one ultimate of the upper stream, this refers to the non-returner.

The reason for this is that the fruit of the non-returner is explained, the five lower fetters are explained, and the cutting off of desire and love is explained, and this also explains the one ultimate of the upper stream.
The wise do not skip stages, gradually with subtle subtlety,
Like a skilled craftsman gradually removes defilements, purifying all impurities.

As for the wise do not skip stages, they are well-versed in the past and present, discerning right from wrong, without diminishing in wisdom, and their nature is not lazy. Therefore it is said, the wise do not skip stages.
As for gradually with subtle subtlety, they should make daily progress without giving up halfway, just as a skilled craftsman removes heavy defilements over time to complete the task.
The removal of mental defilements is also like this. It is praised by the devas, asuras, gandharvas, mahoragas, and others.ğŸ”½Just as a skilled chariot-maker
can skillfully repair a worn-out chariot,
following desire, one can extinguish desire, and later will certainly experience lasting peace and comfort.
Just like that skilled chariot-maker, observing that worn-out chariot, repairing and adorning it, able to travel far with a heavy load without any damage, he then accomplishes two things.
What are the two?
First, his fame spreads far and wide; second, he obtains wealth and goods.

That skilled bhiká¹£u is also like this. He only abandons desire and obtains two praises. His reputation spreads far and wide, and he is praised by the devas. In the present life, he experiences immeasurable happiness.
Therefore it is said:ğŸ”½Just as a skilled chariot-maker
can skillfully repair a worn-out chariot,
following desire, one can extinguish desire, and later will certainly experience lasting peace and comfort.
At that time, the assembly, having heard the Buddha's teachings, departed with joy.
If one wishes to experience all pleasures, one should abandon all desires and attachments.
Having abandoned all desires and attachments, one will eternally experience boundless bliss.

If there are sentient beings who wish to experience all pleasures, they should contemplate the bliss of the four limbs and five limbs of meditation, the bliss of practicing spiritual powers, and the bliss of the path leading to liberation. Those people should contemplate abandoning all desires and attachments. Having abandoned all desires and attachments, they will obtain merit and experience boundless bliss, attain the bliss of play, encounter the bliss of meritorious karma, and in the present life, worldly wealth will not be lacking.
In the past, non-Buddhist practitioners each said, The union of two and two is pure, and one will attain liberation and escape from the cycle of rebirth.

Some also said, Desire is wonderful and pure. One should enjoy oneself with desire, and desire is never satiated. In order to eliminate their doubts about desire, it is said that following desire can extinguish desire, and one will certainly experience eternal peace and well-being in the future.
If one does not contemplate desire and is disgusted with it, how can one cultivate meditation?
Regretful thoughts follow the basis of practice, wisdom can cure and stop them.

If sentient beings contemplate desire and do not let go, their minds will give rise to defilements, just as if a person were near a large fire pit, the closer they get, the hotter it becomes. If they want to avoid the heat, they should seek skillful means to extinguish the fire.

People are also like this. If they do not contemplate desire, desire will naturally cease, just as if there were a poison with an attractive color, a fragrant smell, and a sweet taste. If a person encounters an illness and takes this medicine, it will pass through the throat and enter the stomach, but before long it will take their life.
Desire is also like this. At that time, it delights the mind, but engaging in improper sexual activity will lead to rebirth in hell after the body perishes and life ends.
Now I will draw an analogy. The wise understand themselves through analogies.
In the past, on the land of JambudvÄ«pa, there was a King MÄndhÄtá¹› who appeared in the world, with a lifespan of 1.4 billion years.

At that time, King MÅ«rdhaja was touring the four directions and arrived at the Heaven of the Thirty-three. Because thirty-six Åšakras had taken their last lives there, he stayed in that heavenly palace.
At that time, the human king had passed a long time and thought like this:

My lifespan now exceeds the lifespan of the gods. I have personally seen with my own eyes that thirty-six Åšakras have all taken their last lives. I should now kill Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra and rule the four continents from here as the king of humans and gods. Wouldn't that be joyful?
Having had this thought, he lost his spiritual powers and fell back into the world, staying in JambudvÄ«pa, suffering from bodily pain and experiencing various afflictions.
At that time, the king's ministers asked the king:
Your illness is serious now, and you may be approaching the afterlife. If there are people who come to ask, what instructions does King MÅ«rdhaja have as he is about to die?
At that time, King MÅ«rdhaja told his ministers:
If there are people who come to ask you, you should give this message:
'The King of the Peak was greedy for the five desires and the seven treasures, and was insatiable;
The King of the Peak gave birth to a thousand sons and was insatiable;
The King of the Peak ruled the four continents and was insatiable, and so he met his end;
The King of the Peak rained down the seven treasures from his palace for seven days and seven nights and was insatiable, and so he met his end;
The King of the Peak went to the palace of the Heaven of the Thirty-three and had the intention to harm Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, and so he met his end.'
Therefore it is said:
Not thinking of desires as having enough, how can one cultivate meditation?
Regretful thoughts follow the basis, wisdom cures and stops them.

At that time, all those who came to the assembly were free from desire and had no greedy or attached minds, and all gave rise to the intention of the unsurpassed true path.ğŸ”½Those who are content with wisdom do not look at desire and love again,
People who are content with wisdom do not follow the traces of desire and love.
As for those who are content with wisdom, why is it said that those who are content with wisdom?

They share the same Dharma room with the World-Honored Ones, and with the Realized Ones and Arhats, they contemplate impure practices to give rise to a mind of disgust and eliminate all afflictions and suffering, knowing the origin of suffering.
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, contemplate wisdom. Therefore it is said:
As for those who are content with wisdom, they no longer observe desires and love. Those who desire know their essence, which is real, and do not associate with them.
What was once loved and attached to is now already far removed. The wise are careful not to become tainted and attached to desires.
At that time, the assembly heard this explanation of desires and gave rise to impure thoughts. They then attained dhÄraá¹‡Ä« right on their seats.
People who greedily cling to love and desire, and engage in unrighteous practices,
Do not observe the arrival of death and life, considering life to be long-lasting.
Formerly the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Garden in the kingdom of Shravasti.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
There was a man who lived in poverty and lacked wealth and goods. He suffered hardships and worked hard, going all around the four directions to obtain treasures.
The treasures he obtained were immeasurable. He returned home from afar and shared the joy with his parents and five relatives. In the great assembly, he boasted and said:

I have now obtained treasures worth many millions. I will now marry a woman from a prominent family. She will be neither too fat nor too thin, neither too white nor too black, and will possess all the beauty and charm of a woman.

She will be as beautiful as a peach blossom. I will further adorn her body with fragrant flowers, grease, and powder. We will enjoy ourselves together day and night without being able to part. The food and drink will be different every day. I will kill countless beings, indulging in pleasures without a match. But then I will fall ill and die.
Seeing that his wife has passed away, his mind is confused and his thoughts are disturbed. He ends up going mad and wanders through the streets and alleys, complaining as he goes.
How cruel!

The ghost-killer is unrighteous and has harmed the life of my wife. It is also the case that the relatives and five kinsmen of these people harbor jealous thoughts and each gives rise to this intention, wanting to take away my wife. Fearing that the matter will be exposed, they secretly collude and plot to harm my wife.
In this way, his complaints continued day after day without cease.

At that time, the World-Honored One used his heavenly eye, which is pure and free from defilements, to observe this man's complaints in the streets and alleys. His mind and thoughts were confused and he did not recognize what was right and true.
